5Gkpax3cbqmkfepXv9qolQ.text: Authentic street Mexican food, located in the heart of London with amazing views of the river and city. Once you eat here, you will never want to go to any other Mexican restaurant apart from the other Wahaca's in other locations.

qOFLe_6h2kkz_c9RcBPftw.text: service was excellent. from bar staff to awesome waiter. interior was fairly stunning. but really the food left a lot to be desired. look elsewhere for real mex food.

4ruuAKXk6R98tV4aEXuU7Q.text: This is the worst Wahaca we have been to, and it's the fifth one we visited!We are regulars at the soho branch and it's by far the best.Firstly, there was a sick waiter coughing and sneezing all over the place! We actually had to point it out for him to stop.Secondly, the horchata drinks were too watery.Thirdly, all the food was bland. In fact, our favourite dish, the Sonora salad, we had to actually refuse to pay for it. That was a first for us.It would be a real shame for someone to come to this particular branch for their first Wahaca experience. It is simply not good enough. In fact it is awful.Go to Wahaca in Soho or in Covent Garden instead.We can't help but think that Wahaca is spreading itself too thinly, expanding way too fast and at the cost of high standards. A shame.

9koknP8faLi8BwtSV1Kzew.text: A great Mexican restaurant (though not really authentic) right across from Waterloo Station. It has a fun vibe and the food is very tasty. It is normal that each person in the party pick 2-3 small plates and share, making the options for your meal almost endless. The flavours are fresh and they have fun combinations of different foods. The menu is seasonal as well, so there's always something new to try. Definitely recommend! I've had their tacos, tostadas, quesadillas, taquitos and their guac, and all were delicious! There are many options for vegetarians as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. The tostadas were great--filled to the brim with lots of flavour.

eINOkiOnO5a48g_rCvRAVw.text: Tightly packed tables greet you to a loud, festive basement. It's overheated and uncomfortable. The drinks are average for London and the service is satisfactory. The food is a hot mess. We had some small plates as well as larger dishes. The chicken empanadas were good. The wings had good flavor. The chicken burrito was gloppy and overloaded with off-tasting spices. The guacamole was made from old avocados. You know the taste - musty and gross. Chicken taquitos were greasy but okay. The queso fundido was disgusting. It was a dish full of grilled peppers, tomatoes, and onions with a bit of cheese melted on top, plus some outrageously spicy sausage bits on top, piled high with chopped red onions and cilantro. I adore queso fundido, and this was an abomination. I suppose if one deliberately misspells Oaxaca to be cute, one who patronizes such an establishment should expect to be deliberately cheated out of authentic Mexican cuisine. Go down the street to Fire House. You'll be grateful you did.

xRYZN_bbeaXwWh8e0DAp9w.text: What a fun meal!  The atmosphere was great, the drinks were on point, and the food was creative and delish!  We were visiting from LA and NY, and our local London friends asked us to Wahaca for our last meal before returning to the States.  It was a great time, and I'd definitely come again!

RnDgbzKFTIfXsMdW6nCDRw.text: Really tasty Mexican style food right near Waterloo station. They have a fair amount of vegetarian options and a selection of drinks, including a range of tequilas and a few aqua frescas, including horchata. They do small tapas-like sharing dishes, nibbles and full dishes. I got horchata, guac and chips, plantain tacos and blank bean burritos. It only cost me £13-14. All of it was excellent, but I found the tacos a little too spicy for me. I like the option of small dishes because I usually like a variety of tastes and because I'm small, so full-sized entrees are usually more than I can handle. You also have the option to pay by app. I think for the quality and variety of food that this is really good value for money. I ate at 4pm, so it was nice and quiet and the service was good.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Plantain tacos in front, black bean tostadas behind to the right, guac and chips to the left and horchata in the glass.

FTxYbGQDAWsZlcyDzahiZg.text: The service was awful,  the staff stood and chatted near the bar and didn't acknowledge their customers.  Really  disappointed because  I've been  meaning  to try the place for a long time. The food came cold and late the staff acted busy  but  they weren't.  Really bad awful service never coming here back again. If I could give it a minus star I would . Very annoyed!!! Waste off money

9smFCWsBdw0lxbXYtIogbw.text: Food was ok. Service was so bad we almost walked out. And as non-rushed tourist that is saying something.

FHw2w4ygDD9gLNUszvgClg.text: Star components1 star for drinks (average)2 stars for street mexican in London (above average).5 for decor (eh).5 for foosball table my son liked4 starsThis is a London chain of decent Mexican 'street food' which means tortillas etcQuite good food and very fast serviceMargaritas so-so since London is not a tequila town, why not?  Aren't you all Limeys?This is a fun fast and fresh place I am sure you will like.

ed0YpwkXtdhOHgB1DVGcNQ.text: Super trendy London chain that does small plates of Mexican food, great for sharing. We were a party of 4 and went crazy ordering the tacos (1 pork, 1 plaintain, 2 chicken, and 3 steak), tried a taquito and a quesadilla but I'd say the steak taco is the best. But everything comes in 3s so that may be the ideal group size!

Dwu7RlE5wrCbAY6fuiHi5A.text: I'm a big fan of Wahaca and I recently went to their Waterloo branch for the first time.  I love the interior of the restaurant, it's nicely set out and has great decor.  The place has a buzz to it, a good atmosphere always assists in creating a good meal experience!  We turned up at 8ish on a very busy Thursday with 8 of us and we only had to wait 45 minutes (which meant we could have cocktails, chips and guacamole whilst playing table football!).  We shared 2 of the Mexican Feast set menus with a few extra dishes, which were all delicious.  I especially liked the special cocktail, the Spiked Shandy.  It definitely has a kick from the Tabasco, but is a great drink.  The staff were lovely and helpful, even when we were useless at deciding what we wanted!  I will definitely be back to this branch and Wahaca in general.

D-EBtqVZs8j0_vf45tigaQ.text: I don't understand marketing the overt cheap-chain feel to Wahaca. From the buzzing light transponders that they give their guests in queue (as if the host could not just walk over to the bar to tell you that your table was ready) to the interesting spiel given with full inscription on your menu/place-mat. Do they sing for birthdays too? Our waitress was muted in a sea of outside voices and if not for her drawings on our menu/place-mats as well as our pointing to menu items and nodding, we would have been unable to communicate. Still, I'm not even sure of a single word that she said.That aside, I was whet with anticipation over the responsibly sourced food we were about to consume, despite the over sized dining room, with over sized voices. First round, we split the Guac + Chips and the Frijoles + Chips. Both were very decent, obviously fresh made, and nothing to complain about for a starter snack. We washed these down with a Classic Marg and a Wahaca Mule. I can't speak for the Margarita, but their take on the Moscow Mule subbing Tequila for Vodka is delicious!Wanting to make it simple with all the confusion over pre-ordering instructions and what was offered for specials etc, we kept it basic and went with the tacos, beef and pork. - The beef was a bit dry, lacked enough chipotle salsa, and the uniquely lightly charred cheese was off-putting - The pork was not quite moist, but unfair to call dry. "Special Yucatecan marinade with fiery pickled onions" - yeah... fiery? no. special? ok.Both needed heavy doses of sauce and less cook time. Having been to Mexico, lived in Guatemala and Miami, and visited the SouthWest US Wahaca is not bad, but it's not great either. Kudos on the sustainable sourcing but I would really appreciate the experience more if I felt like I wasn't at one of the cheap establishments that are all too many in the US. This is not a theme park it's a restaurant. All in all, I would dodge it if I was hungry, but I wouldn't brag about it to my friends either...

wWO4RMHo6TakZrvh7gnieA.text: Cool setting! Underground and nice ambiance. Food was great for adults and kids. Service was very good.

lPmI_FKKkTuMAzvumoeUOw.text: Distinctly small supermarket sarnies on a square plate.After seeing the reviews here on yelp, I had hoped I would be in for a treat.  Instead I've had better lunches out of a packet from M&S.Although this lunch was sans wheels, (I'm normally with my offsprog in a pram cos I'm not hipster-mum enough for a sling), the first thing I noticed was just how inaccessible this place is. Not only are there stairs down to the venue, the hand rail is unreachable due to the various shrubberies that line the stair case. Now I'm not exactly a monkey, so I could only just about hold on to the hand rail to totter down in my interview shoes. Inside the acoustics were terrible, probably due to the low ceiling and abundance of metallic interior design. What should have been fresh and summer decor felt like an abandoned Mexican playground with some tables squeezed in. Badly. Our waiter, while nice enough, was really mumbly. It seemed to take forever to find dairy free, which still had to be checked. My poor vegan friend was nearly with out choice. I ended up having a special, a winter steak sarnie... Only it didn't feel that special. The kitchen forgot to remove offending milk products, so I had to wait while my companions ate. It was a thin piece of frying steak that was only just about pink. My vampirism was not to be satisfied! Plus the sandwich was the size of my hand with some miserable tortilla chips, dolefully splattered with some sort of watery tomato salsa. My spicy slaw was ok, but I really like raw cabbage, so it couldn't really fail. The hibiscus mojito was delicious... But sadly so small that it was gone in seconds. Poor vegan accomplice had a winter vegetable burrito, which really was just a rice and mushroom wrap. A real shame she didn't like mushrooms. Even more of a shame were the fried sweet potato. The nicest food one the table and if there was any more than half a potato in that terracotta ketchup pot, then you can tell where you found it please. We didn't even entertain the thought of pudding. We paid the bill and decided gin was a much better option and headed for the near by and delightful Scooter Caffè. Seriously, rather go to M&S, get 4 times the amount of food and eat it in a park where I can hear my friends and avoid depressed nacho chips.

66lueJCsXdGWmDmXcnwTZg.text: Love Wahahca. Tasty, fresh food, comes quickly - great cocktails too. Does get very busy so be prepared for a wait, or try and come early. Really handy for waterloo station - almost opposite. Good selection of vegetarian options and even a gluten free menu if you want it.

117_19x0lXKumEmVVZ-1ig.text: This is Wahaca's newest addition and is perfectly placed on the Waterloo Road in easy reach of station users. Award-winning Mexican street food, cocktails and tequila bar with daily specials and a friendly, attentive staff. After ordering 3 dishes to share, we couldn't stop and ordered 2 more. Can thoroughly recommend the pork pil-pil tacos and ceviche tostadas. The virgin mojito is outstanding and a snip at £2.95. Once you have had the guacamole with fennel pork scratchings, you'll never go back to tortilla chips! I'll be refuelling here as often as I can.

8544UaaFwvLymcXz4xQE1Q.text: Reasonably priced and serving time is quick. The food is not totally authentic, although it's a chain restaurant, so that's kind of expected. I liked that you could choose a couple of small sized dishes, so that you can have variety. I got two dishes and was pretty full. Also, this place is great if you're with friends or family.

ZOZifRj82fh5VTxh4QJynw.text: I have never come away disappointed with eating at Wahaca.  The service is great,  the atmosphere is fun and the food is exceptional.  I love the interior of this branch also.  There are many options for vegetarians,  I'm often spoilt for choice,  which can be rare. Thier drinks and cocktails are also brilliant.

kCDDb7UOqeq-FSIr0zfBgQ.text: Let me be clear from the start - this is a review based on an attempt to eat at Wahaca in Waterloo. We did not end up having a meal there because of the outrageously rude host and hostess. In short, we put our names down for a table and went outside, armed with a pager to alert us when our table was ready. After about 20 minutes, the pager starts to buzz. Five minutes later, we approach the host, who informs us that he has given our table away due to our FIVE MINUTE lag. When we protested, suggesting that five minutes was not nearly a sufficient amount of time to justify giving our table away, his response was: "You admitted it took you five minutes." Yes, we did admit it took us five minutes, which seems like a more than reasonable amount of time to hold a table (especially for a group that is in possession of a pager...it's not like we put our names down just to score a useless pager and then walked away). Moreover, we were never alerted that we had a three minute window between being paged and approaching the host. Having eaten at other Wahacas, I can attest to the fact that the food is mediocre. But with service like this, I can see no justification for giving this restaurant (certainly the Waterloo branch) any future business. You're better off heading to one of the new burrito chains that are popping up all over London.

iZoWAptICeyJrpj8qazv_w.text: First thing's first, I love Wahaca. I rave about it and always tell people to eat there. I've eaten at the ones in Stratford and Canary Wharf, but tonight was my first time eating at Wahaca in Waterloo. I brought my entire family to try it for the first time but the hostess was not friendly at all. She told us we would have to wait 1 hour and 20 minutes for our table and so I gave her my name and we went to walk around Southwark. About 20 minutes passed and my little sister said she needed food and couldn't wait any longer. I told her we could eat at the Wahaca food cart outside and then go back to the restaurant in time for dessert since I had been talking about the chocolate and the churros for a long time. We ate our burritos (which were tasty) and killed some time so we could have our dessert. We went into the restaurant when the time was right and they seated us right away. We told them we wanted to see the dessert menu and our waiter brought the menus out to us and then told a co-worker, maybe a manager, that we just wanted to order dessert and not food. Next thing I know, he came over and told us that the tables we were sitting at were only for people who wanted to have a meal. He told us that we should not just go into the restaurant to have dessert, even if we were waiting for an hour and 20 minutes! He said that this was the only time they were going to let us have dessert and to "not do it next time". It was absolutely ridiculous and I was so angry it ruined my dessert! He had no right to tell us what we could order and couldn't order. I couldn't believe how horrible the staff were after I had had such impeccable service from the ones in East London.

XUItL6ipgC8ahJ44r9vOkw.text: I love Wahaca, but, this particular branch is possibly the loudest restaurant I've ever been in.  Reassuringly, the punters are the usual young 'suits' that have always populated the food and drink establishments of waterloo (unlike say, The Young Vic, now saturated with young Tories), but due to the fact it's a concrete basement, the noise is INSANE. I'd hazard to say it defies one or two EU noise regulations. Avoid this branch. Go to the south bank instead where the tourists are politely quieter.  Alternatively the Cheapside branch is only a pleasing 20 minute walk away. Your ear holes will appreciate it. Sorry for sounding old.

VioBlAefHzH7ojUHxArn1w.text: Food poisoned by wahaca this time last year. Have I heard from them? Any explanation? Compensation? Apology? Nada!!!! wahaca no me gusta.

QXbjFvRECrQFlk8WyiII7w.text: I was delightfully surprised at how good this place was! We started with the chips and guacamole, classic margarita and a hibiscus gin and tonic with black pepper. Really enjoyed the sweet potato and feta taquito, finished off with the taco shade plate. The flavors were really good and surprisingly unique. Our waiter told us that have 30+ restaurants across England. The only bad thing I had was the chips, they were a little dry and stale, not like the freshly made ones we get at home in CA.

m1wN2LHaQ-hkszZ6ni-4Mw.text: Look, I'm not British and have Hispanic relatives so this may be biased from the British viewpoint, but any restaurant that uses the phonetic spelling of Oaxaca (Wahaca) can't be good. In fact, in the US it would be considered gratuitous at best. Also, any "Mexican" restaurant that gives you bottled hot sauces when you ask for the best has got to be bad. And in fact it was bad. Someone needs to tell these people that baba is not Mexican, that horchata is not supposed to be the color and taste of dirty dish water, and limes and cilantro really do exist. This may be the British taste buds that keep this open, but don't insult Mexicans for calling this place what it is not.

eKx6-XKKn0jqpyt1ltnTaQ.text: I always order the same dishes at Wahaca: steak and cheese tacos and bean and corn salad. The salad was fine but the steak in the tacos was undercooked. I thought it'd be a fluke so added a special fried squid dish which was over cooked and chewy. Also the squid tasted fishy which usually means it's not fresh. I'll try Wahaca again but not this location.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Squid wasn't lightly fried and tasted oily and rubbery.

BZcl8zmEiJZmA3TcfqStTA.text: Nice lunch spot in the area! There are few good venues around there, i.e. places where you can sit down to enjoy a proper lunch, but this is one of them. I had the tortilla chips with guacamole, both delicious, as well as the quesadillas with chicken, also very good. I would rcommend this place.

Iq5ioTwCv09_YonmIpjwfA.text: Great atmosphere, kind of hip. You gotta go for the market treats though rather than for a big meal. Prices are ok, considering it's right at Waterloo Station.

-9R_dtt_EyFuDyrdME_HwA.text: Wahaca is one of my favourite restaurant chains, both for their delicious food and fun atmosphere. The restaurant itself is very colourful and modern, which I think helps improve your mood and get you excited for the cocktails and the food.You can choose between smaller dishes to share or regular mains for each person, so it's great for groups and people who would like to try out a few things, and everyone else of course. Another thing I greatly enjoy is that the food itself is tasty with great flavours but the mild food is actually mild. I am not a fun of very hot foods and this is exactly the level I like. However, my friends who love hot food were also happy with the level of spicy that the spicy dishes were at. So no matter what your tolerance is, you will find something for you.I'd recommend checking one of their restaurants out and ideally going later so you can then stay for more drinks. Dinner before a night out would be ideal!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

U7zV1NLqBs31fU9Lq9lrhA.text: my friend and i went to wahaca on a thursday night, we had to wait about 20 minutes for a table during which time we got margaritas. for the price ($10), the margaritas were just okay - nothing i would go back for. we asked for frozen margaritas and got margaritas with crushed ice instead of blended like we expected.after about 15 minutes of waiting we changed our minds and decided to get something to go from the wahaca food truck instead of waiting for a table to clear up. we both got burritos and they were delicious! really quite good. the meat was well cooked, the rice was flavorful, and the toppings were fresh.

2rYf6M7nVvtNG4FiwhZEnQ.text: Wahaca manages to achieve the almost impossible mission of success without decline. Each branch that opens has a slightly new take on the bright Mexican street food eatery selling healthy South American tapas and the best tequila in town, all at mega affordable prices.  I have never had a bad meal or a bad margherita at Wahaca. These guys know what they're doing. Whether it's a crunchy chicken ceaser tostada, a crispy sweet potato & feta taquito or a delicious pork pibl taco, the mini dishes are a dream. Load up and enjoy! The bigger dishes are great too, whether you're into fish tacos, burritos or a salad where you can literally eat the bowl, it's all great! Make sure you start off with THE best guacamole and chips, and end with the decadent churros with chocolate sauce to complete your Wahaca experience. And don't forget the tequila! This location is nicely hidden away and so should be easier to find a seat!

3U1a3GVgb-F-QtvzF5q7Ig.text: Damn, I love Wahaca. Some might complain that it's not quite proper Mexican but that doesn't make it any less tasty. This branch is conveniently located opposite Waterloo station and right near the Old Vic.Inside we always have the same minor trouble - the seating is rather crammed in and the lighting is a bit dim. Our waitress today was good even if the person taking us to the table was a little surly.But onto the good stuff - the pork pibil tacos today were fantastic, and I love the chicken taquitos. But one of our favourites is the sweet potato sides - they're so good that we can't share and have to get a portion each now! We decided to try the steak burrito as well, and were very pleased with the quality of the steak.Another great feature is the quick pay system. Using a QR code on the table and an app, you can pay over your phone meaning that there's no need to wait for the bill to arrive.

ECnudTvEvgYPc6_HPu5G_Q.text: I've tried a lot of Mexican restaurants in London over the years and most are universally terrible.  Wahaca is not.  While a chain, the food is served at a high standard along with being very reasonably priced for London.  I had a frozen margarita and one on the rocks--both were good (I think the rocks was slightly better).  I recommend starting with the pork pibil taco for £4.25--flavorful and spicy.  I tried a bite of my friend's beef taco and didn't think it was nearly as good as the pork.  Next I had the Chilli Quesadilla for £3.95--sweet sautéed onions and jalapeño chillies with feta. They even have habanero salsa on the table so you can heat it up more.Bottom line, I'm from Texas and eat TexMex at least twice a month and I found the food at Wahaca to sufficiently spicy and tasty. The only minor point I have is that at the height of rush-hour on a Thursday night, I found the basement setting to be a bit loud. That was offset, though, by a strong sustainability vibe which I enjoyed (for instance, quirky matchbooks to plant growing guerrilla chillis in the city) and free wifi (which for someone traveling without a data roaming plan, is extremely helpful).Highly recommend.

MA4YrkcjnU9l_Yaw2Q4aag.text: I usually love Wahaca, but this Waterloo branch is substandard: our first visit was fine if a bit crowded and noisy, but we've had undercooked or burnt food on our last 3 visits. Mouldy greenish feta on the last visit, waiter agreed dishes smelt off, offered to replace but we'd been put off our meals.Gave the place a the benefit of the doubt a couple of times, but really felt like the staff were just far too overworked, both in the kitchen and on the floor, hence poor food and incredibly slow service. I strongly recommend you avoid this Wahaca and instead walk a bit further down to the Thames and eat at the one by Southbank.

7GMgRQ9GXlG0qBUN029FNw.text: Food was great. Margaritas were tasty. Prices were very reasonable. Our server, Maya, was awesome!

uvrVtdTrtigHHuCP_0I9HQ.text: First visit - ignored at reception, until a rushed waiter hurried us through the crowded restaurant to a two-seat table. As it was a crowded corner that echoed all the noise in the entire restaurant, I asked if we could sit in the front, at one of the three, pity tables... "No, those are not available." the waiter rushed is to sit down. Noise I can deal with. But being rushed and ignored by staff, coupled with the noise... I'll take my business elsewhere. And as we left, without ordering, no one from the restaurant asked if there was a problem. C

yVv6k5EThXjfLmxKS3lgoA.text: After being told about Wahaca several times, I could not wait to tuck into some Mexican street food! The restaurant itself has a very modern funky vibe with a nice layout. Staff very attentive and punctual with ordering food/drinks.As a main meal, it is recommended to order 2-3 dishes per person. My dishes were all packed with flavour, fresh ingredients and presented nicely! Only downside I can think of is that dishes arrive to the table as and when they are ready - on a table of 4, this can get a little cramped! Also have a separate specials and gf menu, so dont forget to ask for these! Overall I will definitely be returning to Wahaca. Delicious food at a very reasonable price!  Cannot wait until this chain expands up north!

uZA0c4zeHrhizg0mimGNrw.text: Wahaca is my favourite chain of sit-down Mexican restaurant in London. Sure, there are pricier options with more authentic flavours like Lupita (yelp.com/biz/lupita-lond…) and faster more affordable choices like Tortilla (yelp.com/biz/tortilla-lo…). But I think Wahaca offers delicious Mexican food at a mid-range price point.***I came here with two friends sometime during the opening week. The restaurant was still short staffed, and the staff was obviously still getting used the new setting. My friends and I were seated immediately, but we sat at our table for a looong time before the waitress (yes, the one waitress) attended out table. She was out of breath, rattling off the specials at the speed of light, sweaty, and clearly exhausted. Pobrecita!Other than the slowness in service, the food was delicious. We ordered the chips and guacamole, fish and chicken tostadas, and sweet potatoes on the side. The kitchen graciously re-fired a dish for me that conflicted with my food allergies. The restaurant's bright interior creates a delightful atmosphere for a fun meal. One of my favourite features is the sink at the entrance that ensure that you don't get a mouthful of germs with your quesadillas! ***NB: I mean, it's still over-priced. Americans like myself will always think that Mexican food is over-priced because we can get authentic Latino food for cheap in States. But, all things considered, Wahaca is affordable for London Zone 1.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Side of sweet potatoes.
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Water served in tequila bottles makes hydration way more wild lol.
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Chips & guac #classic

NRe9dMaEqooQUV4RkmORsg.text: They print a link to their Yelp page on the receipt asking for reviews yet I'm only the fourth? Well here goes... This was a damn good Mexican make no mistake, we were seated quickly despite being told we were looking at a 40 minute wait, it was probably only actually 10.Tuesday night but the place was packed, usually a good sign. Our waitress was efficient and explained the menu well, we ordered a bunch of dishes. My bestie is a veggie and she was very impressed with the selection of vegetarian dishes available. The food arrives as and when it's ready, it's not ordered into starters and mains and your whole party probably won't get your food simultaneously. Just relax and take it as it comes. Everything we ordered was delicious. Two of us racked up a bill of around £45 and it was worth every penny.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Illuminated stair plants. Every restaurant should have them.
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Spicy coleslaw

1JSvDQR61WfK6nhUnCjNZw.text: What a widespread chain. Packed on Saturday nights, Mexican food for cheap.Protip: the tequila sampler is good even for discerning taste buds. Although the blanco is far too harsh (i much prefer the Anejo, Reposado, and Sangrita in that order)  you can perhaps pass it off to a less discerning friend who just wants to TAKE A SHOTT!!!Protip 2: free foozball table, play a few rounds after the tequila sampler.Don't bother with the fish main for £9, was underwhelming. Street food especially tacos is done well; nice take using British ingredients, but obviously not as good as Chicago Mexican food. Pretty darn close though.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Mmmm tacos or tortas
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Tequila sampler

jylFVj-gIfwhWQQb1ggxwg.text: My love of wahaca has gone!The first time I went to wahacs I was genuinely wowed- fresh, spicy and different food and over the years I have been probably 20 times with friends, family and colleagues. This visit will be my last as wahaca has lost its soul.Smaller portions of guacamole (£4.50), dry pork pibil, slow waitresses, more ice in my drink than the drink itself. Clearly this is all in pursuit of increased profit but this has vastly diminished the experience. What a shame....

bKSXLlF2DC71oDmj88sTYQ.text: Great service and food, even though some of us were kind of disappointed with their choice. The interior is very unique and welcoming. I'd definitely come again. :)

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Great salad with flavorful chicken.

ljPZwCmA2GBP6VPpwKh_gQ.text: After accidentally eating at Wahaca two days in a row, I can say I'm very impressed. After having the sweet potato and feta taquitos, I knew they were going to make a repeat appearance in my life. Their winter vegetables burrito was pretty tasty, and a different combination of veggies than usually included! It also came with a side of tortilla chips of the perfect thickness. The drinks menu is actually great and not that expensive. They had a special - the blood orange margarita - which was so tasty we ordered an entire round. They have a number of vegetarian dishes, but I believe the meat and fish are all sustainably raised. After years of avoiding Wahaca because of its reputation as "commercial Mexican", I've completely changed my mind and am ready for a return visit.Update: second time, and Wahaca still doesn't understand "no beans - I am allergic" despite having a "tell us about your allergies" statement, so I'm deducting a star.
